tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: The writer speaks as a father teaching his child using poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: do not forget my commands
tn.text: The word "commands" can be translated as a verb. AT: "do not forget what I command you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: keep my teachings in your heart
tn.text: This phrase says in positive terms what the previous phrase says in negative terms. Here the word "heart" represents the mind. The word "teachings" can be translated as a verb. AT: "always remember what I teach you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: length of days and years of life
tn.text: These two phrases share similar meanings and refer to living a long life. AT: "a long life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Do not let covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness ever leave you
tn.text: The writer speaks of "covenant faithfulness" and "trustworthiness" as if they were people who could leave someone. The negative command can be stated positively. AT: "Make sure always to practice covenant faithfulness and to be trustworthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: tie them together about your neck
tn.text: The writer speaks of faithfulness and trustworthiness as if they were objects that a person could tie around the neck like a necklace. The image suggests that these are valuable things that the person displays outwardly. AT: "display them proudly like one would wear a necklace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: write them on the tablet of your heart
tn.text: Here the heart represents a person's mind. The mind is spoken of as if it were a tablet upon which someone can write messages and commands. AT: "always remember them, as if you had written them permanently on a tablet" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: in the sight of God and man
tn.text: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. AT: "in the judgment of God and man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: all your heart
tn.text: Here the word "heart" represents the inner person. AT: "your whole being" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: do not lean on your own understanding
tn.text: The writer speaks of relying on one's own understanding as if "understanding" were an object on which a person can lean. AT: "do not rely on your own understanding" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: in all your ways
tn.text: The writer speaks of a person's actions as if they were paths on which the person walks. AT: "in everything you do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he will make your paths straight
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh making a person's actions prosperous as if that person's actions were paths on which he walks and which Yahweh makes free of obstacles. AT: "he will give you success" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do not be wise in your own eyes
tn.text: The writer speaks of a person's opinion as if that person were seeing something with his eyes. AT: "Do not be wise in your own opinion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: turn away from evil
tn.text: The writer speaks of not committing evil actions as if it were turning away from evil. AT: "do not commit evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: It will be healing to your flesh
tn.text: The word "it" refers to the instructions that the writer gives in the previous verse. The full meaning of this can be made clear. The word "flesh" represents the whole body. AT: "If you do this, it will be healing for your body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: produce
tn.text: "harvest"

tn.ref: your storehouses will be filled up
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "your storehouses will be full" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: storehouses
tn.text: buildings or rooms where food is stored

tn.ref: your vats will be bursting
tn.text: your storage containers will be extremely full, as if ready to break open.

tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: The writer writes as a father teaching his son.

tn.ref: a son who pleases him
tn.text: "a son in whom he delights." This refers to the father's affection for the son, and not to the father's approval of the son's behavior. AT: "a son whom he loves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The one who finds wisdom
tn.text: The writer speaks of "wisdom" as if it were an object that one finds. AT: "The one who attains wisdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: what silver will give in return
tn.text: This refers to the profit that one can make from trading or investing silver.

tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: The author speaks of wisdom as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: precious
tn.text: "valuable" or "costly"

tn.ref: She has length of days in her right hand; in her left hand are riches and honor
tn.text: The writer speak of the benefits that one gains from having wisdom as if wisdom were a woman who held these qualities in her hands and offered them to people. AT: "Wisdom gives a person length of days and riches and honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: length of days
tn.text: This idiom refers to a long life. AT: "long life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Her ways are ways of kindness and all her paths are peace
tn.text: The writer speaks of wisdom as if it were a woman and of the benefits that wisdom gives a person as if wisdom were leading that person along a path. AT: "Wisdom will always treat you kindly and give you peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: She is a tree of life to those who take hold of it
tn.text: The writer speaks of wisdom as if it were a tree that bears life-giving fruit and of a person who benefits from wisdom as if that person ate of the fruit. AT: "Wisdom is like a tree that sustains the life of those who eat of its fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a tree of life
tn.text: "a tree that gives life" or "a tree whose fruit sustains life"

tn.ref: those who hold on to it
tn.text: "those who hold on to its fruit"

tn.ref: Yahweh founded the earth ... established the heavens
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh creating the earth and the heavens as if he were laying the foundation of a building. AT: "Yahweh created the earth ... made the heavens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the depths broke open
tn.text: In ancient thought, water existed under the earth. This phrase refers to Yahweh causing that water to come out of the earth and make the oceans and rivers exist. AT: "he caused the rivers to flow" or "he caused the oceans to exist" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: dew
tn.text: water that forms on the ground at night

tn.ref: do not lose sight of them
tn.text: The writer speaks of not forgetting something as if it were always being able to see it. AT: "do not forget them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: They will be life to your soul
tn.text: Here the word "soul" represents the person. AT: "They will be life for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: an adornment of favor to wear around your neck
tn.text: The writer speaks of "sound judgment" and "discernment" as if they were objects that a person could tie around the neck like a necklace. The image suggests that these are valuable things that the person displays outwardly. AT: "a display of favor like one would adorn themselves with a necklace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: adornment of favor
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "a favorable adornment" or 2) "an adornment that displays Yahweh's favor."

tn.ref: you will walk on your way in safety
tn.text: The writer speaks of living one's life as if the person were walking along a path. AT: "you will live your life in safety" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: your foot will not stumble
tn.text: The word "foot" represents the whole person. The writer speaks of doing wrong as if a person stumbled over an object in his path. AT: "you will not do things that are wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: when you lie down
tn.text: It is implied that a person lies down in order to sleep. The meaning of this can be made clear. AT: "when you lie down to sleep" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: your sleep will be sweet
tn.text: The writer speaks of sleep that is peaceful and refreshing as if it tasted sweet to the person sleeping. The word "sleep" can be translated as a verb. AT: "your sleep will be pleasant" or "you will sleep peacefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: devastation caused by the wicked, when it comes
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "when the wicked cause devastation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Yahweh will be on your side
tn.text: "Yahweh will be by your side." A person standing by another person's side is an idiom that means that the one person will help and support the other. AT: "Yahweh will support and defend you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: will keep your foot from being caught in a trap
tn.text: The writer speaks of a person experiencing harm from "terror" and "devastation" as if the person were caught in a trap. The word "foot" represents the whole person. AT: "will protect you from those who want to harm you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Do not withhold good
tn.text: "Do not withhold good things" or "Do not withhold good actions"

tn.ref: when it is in your power to act
tn.text: "when you are able to help"

tn.ref: when you have the money with you
tn.text: "when you have the money with you now." The meaning here is that the person has the money to help today, but tells his neighbor to come back tomorrow.

tn.ref: Do not ... choose any of his ways
tn.text: It is implied that he is not to choose to imitate the actions of the violent person. AT: "Do not ... choose to imitate any of his ways" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the devious person is detestable to Yahweh
tn.text: "Yahweh detests the devious person"

tn.ref: the devious person
tn.text: the person who is dishonest or deceitful

tn.ref: he brings the upright person into his confidence
tn.text: Yahweh shares his thoughts with the those who do right as with a close, trusted friend. AT: "Yahweh is a close friend to the upright" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The curse of Yahweh is on the house of the wicked person
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh's curse as if it were an object that he placed on top of the wicked person's house. The word "house" is a metonym for family. AT: "Yahweh has cursed the family of the wicked person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he blesses the home of righteous people
tn.text: The word "home" represents the family. AT: "he blesses the families of righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he gives his favor to humble people
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh's favor as if it were an object that he gives to people. AT: "he shows his favor to humble people" or "he is gracious to humble people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Wise people inherit honor
tn.text: The writer speaks of wise people obtaining a reputation of honor as if they inherited honor as a permanent possession. AT: "Wise people will obtain honor" or "Wise people will gain an honorable reputation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: fools will be lifted up in their shame
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh making the shame of fools evident to everyone as if Yahweh were lifting fools up for everyone to see them. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will cause everyone to see the shame of fools" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
